ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments:
- A comprehensive understanding of different military weapons, tactics, infrastructure, strategies, and tools throughout the course of history
- A broad overview of Europe's excursions, conflicts, expansion, and development, and how the bullet point above explains the trajectory of European affairs
- A deep dive into specific battles and why they played out the way they did
Literally everything thing from the Treaty of Westphalia to the Afghanistan War
I developed a deeper understanding of European military history, as well as a better knowledge of general historical trends.
I learned how to read effectively because we had to read many books for this class.
A fairly vague understanding of some events related to military history in the last 500 years.
Military history overview 1500-present.
I learned far more about world history since 1500. I especially enjoyed the discourse on why Europe outpaced the rest of the world in development.
I learned how to effectively narrate the causes and effects of the world power dynamics since 1453.
I understood the important trends relevant to the progress of military branches in the the western world.
Knowledge on military history and grand strategy.
Overview of global history since 1500. How to study a lot of info for the final.
I learned a lot about European history in the 16th, 17th, and 18th centuries that I really knew nothing about before, and I got much better and more efficient at studying for essay-based exams.
Knowledge of Mill history of the west since 1500. Knowledge of how to write strong essays for history

A simultaneously cursory and in-depth look into military history spanning from the 1500s onwards. Detailed analyses of the economic building blocks behind early bureaucracies and how they led to military development, the fiscal-military state and the fiscal-naval state (Britain). Military theory in the form of Clausewitz and Jomini, Smuts, Mitchell, Trenchard, and Douhet. Profiles into great military leaders of the era -- The Duke of Marlborough, Duke of Wellington, Bonaparte, Frederick the Great, etc. A detailed look in the evolution of military technology from the arquebus up to SAM missiles and Predator drones.
Gained a broad sweep view of military history since 1500. Also as a non-history major this class exposed me to the general thought process of constructing a historical narrative.
I learned about history after 1500 in the West.

We learned the story of Western Civilization since 1500 and how it all fits under Professor Kennedy's larger diachronic argument, that the rise and fall of the Great Powers is determined by a number of factors that have almost all to do with the collective and almost nothing to do with the individual.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course's main strength is the broadness of the lectures as a complement to the extremely detailed reading for students to capture a general and meticulous picture of the history. While I heard differing viewpoints on students' section experience, mine happened to be an incredibly useful addendum to our classes since we spoke about new material with a captain who had real-world expertise in the often theoretical concept of sea power.

Strength: Professor Kennedy really knows his history and can competently build a narrative of military history in often surprising ways. My discussion section was also great. 

Weakness: TA training could be better. Some of the rubric instructions were very unclear.

Strengths: Kennedy is a gem, take any class he teaches. 
Weaknesses: Lectures were very loosely organized and took a lot of outside work to connect ideas. Lots of readings that are literally the same thing over and over.
The strength of this course was the instructor.
This content of the course should be learned by all.

Cons: it's pretty broad, skips around a lot, Professor Kennedy's lectures are sometimes interesting, often kind of ramblings. A lot of readings that don't connect to what's discussed in class. Mandatory section.

Pros: sometimes interesting, only required work is the midterm and final.
Awesome lectures. Readings were so dense and long people just stopped doing them. Fewer readings would allow us to engage better.
Great lectures, fair exams. Section was a bit boring at times. Maybe it should be worth more of the grade to encourage more riveting discourse.

Strengths:
Presentations 
Lectures 
Material
Books

Weaknesses:
A bit too generalized
Great workload, great readings, great lectures.
My TA was definitely a weakness. There is a lot of unnecessary reading as well. The reading could be cut down and the same material would be covered.
Professor Kennedy is very interesting and great to watch in lecture. Lecture slides are only pictures, however, and have no writing.

Strengths: Very interesting subject material. 
Weaknesses: A prereq for this class should be a knowledge of military history of the west since 1500. Significant World events are often alluded to, but never actually taught. For example, we will look at planes used during WW2, but will never learn what WW2 was. This would be fine, except a comprehensive knowledge of historical events and their details are required for midterms/finals. The readings for this class are uber-specific and rarely relevant(whole readings on cannon dimensions or wood for ships). In class, it is quite the opposite, clicking through 30 pictures with little explanation.

The readings are enjoyable but fairly repetitive, so it would be nice if the syllabus could be trimmed down or some indication could be given about which readings essentially provide the same information over again. The lectures are fun to listen to, but sometimes wander and can lack clear direction and organization.
great class! No notes! One of the best classes I ever took!

The course was great in that it was structured both conventionally and unconventionally. Kennedy's lectures would feel almost like a "story time," but one could see easily that he was both keeping right on top of the content at hand with his slides and also clearly organizing the lecture around a chronological "major theme of the course." He would flow seamlessly from "small tangents" to detailed looks into the HMS Dreadnought. The readings were manageable, even if sometimes they were burdensome (there was one where he wanted us to do effectively 300 pages of reading in the span of two days fairly close to finals period).
The course is broad and covers very engaging material. The lectures could be too broad sometimes and light on details making it difficult to determine what the biggest ideas were.
The course felt more based on readings than lectures so I wish they could be tied together more.
It is a superb course.  Some of the readings were dense, but otherwise, it was fantastic in every respect.

Strengths - fascinating content, great professor, very interesting readings
Weaknesses - too much reading (almost nobody does it all or close to it)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: For students prepared to do the readings, engage with the material, and add additional research about how different technological evolutions and engagements relate to one another, absolutely. Simply having the privilege to study under Prof. Kennedy's direction makes this course an excellent experience, and students exit with a firm grasp of crucial historical material that is often neglected today.
Not really, unless you need it. I have a feeling that a seminar with Kennedy would be a lot better.

Sure, Professor Kennedy is great, but keep in mind that this is a ROTC class and that the final is literally 60% of your final grade. If you're up for an old school class with a huge reading commitment, blue book exams, and interesting content, this is for you.

I would recommend the course. If you do the readings, you will get a lot out of the course. Professor Kennedy takes things very slow during lecture and focuses on very broad themes in military history, however the discussion section conversations are generally very focused on specific readings. Section can get very dull as doing the readings was largely not necessary as long as you have at least a rudimentary background in military history.
Yes, I would recommend this course. The material is interesting and relevant to today.
Yes.
Yes, I think it is an excellent in-depth military history overview that would benefit any all students.

A great course taught by the man who wrote the book on Great Power Competition. If you're interested in international security you should take this course. The course is taught in the standard history lecture format so it is pretty straightforward and not too difficult.

Maybe, if you have time to do the readings or are willing to cram for the two exams. It's very easy on a weekly basis but they grade is 90% exams and you don't learn everything you need to know for them in lecture so it's easy in terms of workload you actually have to do but hard to do all the readings and hard to do that well on the exams.

Lectures are incredible, gotta take a Kennedy class while you still can. He's a legend. You don't have to do a lot besides midterm and final grind, but overall the class was better when I did the readings and engaged. Section was actually a plus, which is rare.
Yes! Great survey course taught by the legend himself. PMK is a very funny and skilled orator. Take one of his classes before it's too late. You'll regret it if you don't.
Not really. I felt as thought most of the information we learned in this class could have been learned on my own.
I would recommend this course to students who wish to gain an alternative perspective on world history and global affairs.
Yes. Professor Kennedy is a legend and makes the class a pleasure to be a part of.
Yes! It is an interesting overview and you learn a lot if you pay attention in lecture! Great for people with interest in military history but have very little background.
Yes - great for Hu credit or/and if interested in military history.

If you are interested in the subject matter, definitely take it, but don't see it as just an easy course. The reading load is quite substantial if you choose to do all or most of it, and putting the pieces together is a task you'll have to take on yourself.
Yes! Wonderful class

Yes. Professor Kennedy is a wonderful professor and the lectures are incredibly interesting to see, and he will truly give you a complete picture of the state of the military at the time. There are also guest lectures sometimes that are also quite illuminating.
Interesting class that I would recommend to any major. If someone were only to take one history class it does not get much better than a survey course like this.
Yes. it is very interesting and taught by great professor.
Yes it is fundamental.  All Yale students should have a grasp of this kind of history, because it is this kind of thinking that allows us to refine our futures.
No
Yes, fascinating course taught by a legendary professor.
